results.title: Getting court
results.brief_description: Shayne steals a car and is charged with car theft and drunk driving. His friend encourages him to seek legal aid and we follow him into court. An excellent program on stealing and the law.

results.title: Getting away
results.brief_description: Gladys Riggs, bored with her family life in a caravan park, plans to “escape” with a travelling salesman. However, her attempts are thwarted when her son decides to come along. Based on a short story by G. Dorothy Thomas.

results.title: Getting around in French
results.creator_credit: Educational TV Services and Harry Mehlman
results.brief_description: Students from Assumption College, Kilmore and Nunawading HIgh School are shown in a number of situations using French language skills they have acquired from the Eclair French language course. Various situations are depicted and the program concludes with students giving their opinions on the Eclair course of study.

results.title: Getting a handle on stress with Heidi Di Santo
results.brief_description: Stress is a part of most people’s lives and can be traced back to the fight or flight instincts in prehistoric days. Today this problem is confounded by the fact that we are not as reliant on the fight or flight mechanism, and the societal pressures that contribute to stress levels. This program covers areas such as the effects of long term stress, telltale signs that you are suffering from stress, the importance of identifying how you individually react to stress. It also interviews people who have suffered from serious stress and how it has affected their lifestyle, as well as covering the areas of relaxation, disassociation, sleep, exercise, diet, and the dynamic relationship between thought, feeling and reaction. The video is designed to be integrated with the teachers guide and participant workbooks (available as a separate loan item), as part of a 2-4 hour training session on handling stress.

results.title: Get you a Prime Minister who can do both (sing the same verse of April Sun In Cuba twice)
results.brief_description: In an effort to rehabilitate his image after a disastrous week in politics – including shelving his signature religious discrimination bill and what some saw as a disingenuous apology on sexual assault in parliament – Prime Minister Scott Morrison hosted a lengthy interview with 60 Minutes Australia. Promos for the episode quickly circulated on social media, with users lambasting Scott Morrison’s attempt to project a demeanour of goofy familiarity and his peculiar choice of strumming a ukulele – an instrument most popular in Hawaii, where Morrison holidayed at the height of summer bushfires in 2019/20.
results.title_for_label: Get you a Prime Minister who can do both (sing the same verse of April Sun In Cuba twice)
results.description: In an effort to rehabilitate his image after a disastrous week in politics – including shelving his signature religious discrimination bill and what some saw as a disingenuous apology on sexual assault in parliament – Prime Minister Scott Morrison hosted a lengthy interview with 60 Minutes Australia. Promos for the episode quickly circulated on social media, with users lambasting Scott Morrison’s attempt to project a demeanour of goofy familiarity and his peculiar choice of strumming a ukulele – an instrument most popular in Hawaii, where Morrison holidayed at the height of summer bushfires in 2019/20. As you can see below, the footage was remixed by social-media users, who superimposed the footage on different backgrounds, including raging bushfires, while others changed the song from Dragon’s “April Sun in Cuba” to Radiohead’s “Creep” and Denis Leary’s “Asshole”.
description_for_label: In an effort to rehabilitate his image after a disastrous week in politics – including shelving his signature religious discrimination bill and what some saw as a disingenuous apology on sexual assault in parliament – Prime Minister Scott Morrison hosted a lengthy interview with 60 Minutes Australia. Promos for the episode quickly circulated on social media, with users lambasting Scott Morrison’s attempt to project a demeanour of goofy familiarity and his peculiar choice of strumming a ukulele – an instrument most popular in Hawaii, where Morrison holidayed at the height of summer bushfires in 2019/20.

results.title: Get wet again
results.brief_description: More fun with Jonathan Coleman. In this program his nervous “brother” Terry learns to swim - with the assistance of Lisa Forrest. The emphasis is on feeling at ease in the water and includes activities such as blowing bubbles, floating, basic swimming and rescue.

results.title: Get wet
results.brief_description: An exciting invitation to do just what the title recommends. The film is about everyone’s capacity to enjoy water sport, be it in a pool or in the open water of lake or river. Includes some dazzling exhibitions of diving and water skiing.

results.title: Get well stories
results.brief_description: Introduces Dorothy Butler who passionately believes books should play a crucial role in children’s lives. Attempt to encourage children to read, by capitalising on their fascination with the television screen. Uses professional storytellers and well-known stories, giving fully annotated details for each book used.
